docs.title: AIIMS CRE Psychiatric Social Worker: Complete Preparation Guide
Exam Pattern & Syllabus
docs.text:
The AIIMS Common Recruitment Examination (CRE) for Psychiatric Social Worker consists of 100 Multiple Choice Questions (MCQs) worth 400 marks, with a 90-minute duration. The exam follows this pattern:[1]

Section-wise Distribution: - General Section (25 questions, 100 marks): General Intelligence & Reasoning (20 marks) and English Language (20 marks)[2] - Subject Knowledge (75 questions, 300 marks): Social Work and Psychology domain-specific content[2]

Marking Scheme: - Correct Answer: +4 marks - Wrong Answer: -1 mark (25% negative marking) - Exam Language: English only (for technical/graduate posts)[3]

docs.title: A. General Intelligence and Reasoning (20 Marks)
docs.text: Analogies, similarities and differences, space visualization, problem solving, analysis, judgment, decision making, visual memory, discriminating observation, relationship concepts, arithmetical reasoning, verbal and figure classification, arithmetical number series, non-verbal series[2]

docs.title: B. English Language (20 Marks)
docs.text: Spot the Error, Fill in the Blanks, Synonyms/Homonyms, Antonyms, Spellings, Idioms & Phrases, One word substitution, Improvement of Sentences, Active/Passive Voice, Direct/Indirect narration, Shuffling of Sentence parts, Cloze Passage, Comprehension Passage[2]

docs.title: C. Subject Knowledge (50 Marks) - Core Topics
docs.text:
1. Framework: Social Welfare - Concept, need and objectives of Social Welfare - Philosophy of Social Welfare and Social work - Social welfare in historical perspective - Changing concepts and practices of social welfare - Social Welfare and related terms: Social Development, Social Planning, Social Reform, Social Security, Social Policy, Social Action, Social Justice, Social and welfare services, Social legislation, Human Rights[2]

2. Professional Social Work - Concept of professional social work - Evolution in UK, USA, and India - Basic principles and values - Nature and characteristics of a profession - Professional status of Social work in India - Code of ethics for social workers - Methods of Social Work: Primary and Secondary methods - Integrated approach and Interface between Professional and voluntary social work[2]

3. Psychology and Mental Health: Fundamentals - Psychology: Definitions and Fields - Mental Health: Meaning, Definitions, Characteristics - Normal & Abnormal Behaviour: Meaning, Characteristics[2]

4. Human Development - Heredity and Environment - Mental Hygiene: Definition, scope, Characteristics, Importance, Aims, Principles, Programme - Developmental Stages: Prenatal, Infancy, Babyhood, Childhood, Puberty, Adolescence, Adulthood, Middle age, Old age[2]

5. Personality Development Theories - Psycho-Sexual development theory: Sigmund Freud - Psychosocial development theory: Erik Erikson - Defence Mechanisms - Perspectives of Psychopathology[2]

6. Social Psychology - Nature and scope of social psychology - Attitude: nature and measurement, prejudice and discrimination - Communication: concept, methods, skills, major obstacles - Mass communication, public opinion, propaganda, fashion, social facilitation, crowd behaviour[2]

7. Sociology: Theoretical Perspective - Society: Nature, Approaches, Functions, Theories (Evolutionary, Cyclical, Conflict, Systems) - Social Group: Primary, Secondary, Reference Groups - Social Institutions: Family, Marriage, Kinship, Property (Present trends) - Culture: Traditions, Customs, Values and Norms - Social System & Sub-system: Structure & Function - Social Structures: Status & Role - Social Process: Social Interaction, Socialization, Cooperation, Conflict, Assimilation, Social control[2]

docs.title: Detailed 1-Month Study Plan
docs.text:
Study Plan Highlights:

Week 1: Foundation Building - Days 1-2: General Intelligence basics + English fundamentals + Social Welfare concepts - Days 3-4: Reasoning practice + Professional Social Work + Psychology basics - Days 5-6: English comprehension + Human Development + Personality theories - Day 7: Weekly revision + Mock test (General section)

Week 2: Core Psychology & Social Work - Days 8-9: Developmental stages + Defence mechanisms + Social Psychology - Days 10-11: Sociology concepts + Social institutions + Social structures - Days 12-13: Current affairs + Social Work methods + Professional ethics - Day 14: Weekly revision + Subject knowledge mock test

Week 3: Advanced Topics & Integration - Days 15-16: Advanced English + Mental Hygiene + Social Systems - Days 17-18: Reasoning practice + Social legislation + Social processes - Days 19-20: Current affairs updates + Social Policy + Full paper practice - Day 21: Full-length mock test + Comprehensive review

Week 4: Intensive Practice & Final Revision - Days 22-23: High-weightage topics revision + Practice questions (80+) - Days 24-25: Previous year papers analysis + Frequently asked questions - Days 26-27: Weak areas practice + Subject-wise notes review + Mock test - Days 28-29: Final revision + Mock test series (2 tests) + Time management - Day 30: Light revision + Exam strategy + Mental preparation

Daily Schedule (9 hours study): - Morning (9 AM - 12 PM): New topic study or General section - Afternoon (2 PM - 5 PM): Subject knowledge or Conceptual topics - Evening (6 PM - 9 PM): Practice, revision, or mixed topics - Night: Review notes, solve 20-30 practice questions

docs.title: Preparation Strategy & Tips
docs.text:
1. Study Approach: - Start with NCERT books for Psychology and Sociology basics - Use standard Social Work textbooks (MA/MSc level) - Create concise notes for quick revision - Focus on understanding concepts rather than rote learning[13][1]

2. Practice Strategy: - Solve at least 50 questions daily - Attempt 8-10 full-length mock tests - Analyze errors thoroughly after each test - Time yourself strictly (90 minutes for 100 questions)[13][1]

3. Revision Techniques: - Create flashcards for theories and definitions - Use mnemonics for remembering lists - Revise high-weightage topics every 3 days - Make formula sheets and key point summaries[13]

4. Time Management: - Allocate 18 minutes per 20-question section - Don't spend more than 50 seconds per question - Attempt easier questions first - Keep 5-10 minutes for final review[13]

5. Exam Day Strategy: - Start with your strongest section - Skip confusing questions initially - Be cautious with negative marking (avoid random guessing) - Review marked questions if time permits[3][13]

docs.title: AIIMS PSW FollowUp Questions and Connections
docs.text:
AIIMS CRE PSYCHIATRIC SOCIAL WORKER ADVANCED FOLLOW-UP QUESTIONS & TOPIC INTERCONNECTIONS ====================================================================================================

Q1. PRIMARY TOPIC: Freud Psychosexual Development ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

FOLLOW-UP QUESTION: If a person has Oral Fixation showing dependency, what would be their likely defence mechanism?

ANSWER: Projection (blaming others for their neediness) or Displacement (seeking comfort from unhealthy sources)

TOPIC CONNECTIONS: Connects to: Defence Mechanisms, Normal vs Abnormal, Therapeutic Intervention

ARISTOTLE CONNECTION: Virtue of temperance: Seeking pleasure in moderation. Fixation = excess gratification = vice

====================================================================================================

Q2. PRIMARY TOPIC: Freud Psychosexual Development ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

FOLLOW-UP QUESTION: How would Freud explain adolescent mood swings and identity confusion?

ANSWER: Reactivation of Oedipal conflicts from Phallic stage, combined with new genital awareness. Unsolved stage conflicts surfacing.

TOPIC CONNECTIONS: Connects to: Erikson Stage 5 (Identity vs Confusion), Abnormal vs Normal behavior, Mental Health

ARISTOTLE CONNECTION: Both Freud and Aristotle: Adolescence critical period for developing character. Freud: sexual identity; Aristotle: virtue development

====================================================================================================

Q3. PRIMARY TOPIC: Erikson Psychosocial Development ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

FOLLOW-UP QUESTION: A 70-year-old client comes to PSW saying "My life was a waste; I never achieved anything." Which stage is unresolved?

ANSWER: Stage 7: Generativity vs Stagnation - Did not feel they contributed meaningfully; now experiencing despair in Stage 8

TOPIC CONNECTIONS: Connects to: Depression in elderly, Social Support importance, Therapeutic counseling approach

ARISTOTLE CONNECTION: Aristotle: Eudaimonia requires meaningful contribution. Client lacking this = unable to flourish

====================================================================================================

Q4. PRIMARY TOPIC: Mental Health & Mental Hygiene ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

FOLLOW-UP QUESTION: Why does social support improve mental health in depression? Connect to multiple theories.

ANSWER: Trust development (Erikson Stage 1), reduces isolation, provides belonging need (Maslow), activates mature defence (altruism)

TOPIC CONNECTIONS: Connects to: Erikson, Maslow, Defence Mechanisms, Social Psychology (relationships)

ARISTOTLE CONNECTION: Humans are social beings. Connection = essential for eudaimonia. Isolation = inability to flourish

====================================================================================================

Q5. PRIMARY TOPIC: Social Work Methods ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

FOLLOW-UP QUESTION: For treating child sexual abuse victim, why might Group Work be better than only Case Work?

ANSWER: Group provides: Normalization ("I'm not alone"), Peer support, Modeling healthy responses, Reduced shame through mutual support

TOPIC CONNECTIONS: Connects to: Social Support, Defence Mechanisms (shared trauma), Therapeutic relationship

ARISTOTLE CONNECTION: Practical wisdom: Choose method fitting client need. Group work shows prudence in understanding healing needs

====================================================================================================

Q6. PRIMARY TOPIC: Defence Mechanisms ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

FOLLOW-UP QUESTION: How can PSW differentiate between adaptive sublimation and maladaptive acting out in same behavior (exercise)?

ANSWER: Sublimation: Person feels better, relationships improve, achievement continues. Acting out: Person injuries self, relationships suffer, no progress

TOPIC CONNECTIONS: Connects to: Normal vs Abnormal, Therapeutic assessment, Mental Health outcomes

ARISTOTLE CONNECTION: Both involve physical activity (exercise). Virtue ethics: Context and intention matter. Sublimation = virtuous; Acting out = avoidance

====================================================================================================

Q7. PRIMARY TOPIC: Normal vs Abnormal Behavior ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

FOLLOW-UP QUESTION: A man hears voices telling him to help others. He voluntarily works in hospital. Is this abnormal?

ANSWER: Biopsychosocial assessment needed: If hallucinations cause distress/dysfunction, abnormal. If not distressing and he's functioning, may be spiritual experience

TOPIC CONNECTIONS: Connects to: Mental Health definition, Cultural differences, Psychological assessment

ARISTOTLE CONNECTION: Context matters. Aristotle: virtue is contextual. Hearing voices = could be spiritual gift (virtue) or illness depending on context

====================================================================================================

Q8. PRIMARY TOPIC: Social Work Principles & Values ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

FOLLOW-UP QUESTION: You have a client you personally dislike. How do you apply "Principle of Acceptance"?

ANSWER: Separate person from behavior. Recognize your counter-transference. Maintain professional standards despite personal feelings. Reflect on bias.

TOPIC CONNECTIONS: Connects to: Counter-transference management, Professional ethics, Therapeutic relationship

ARISTOTLE CONNECTION: Virtue of Justice: Fair treatment regardless of personal preference. Practical wisdom to manage own emotions professionally

====================================================================================================

Q9. PRIMARY TOPIC: Therapeutic Concepts ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

FOLLOW-UP QUESTION: Client becomes angry at you for "not understanding." But you've been empathetic. What's likely happening?

ANSWER: Transference: Client's past experience of misunderstanding (parent, authority figure) projected onto you. Use therapeutically to explore pattern.

TOPIC CONNECTIONS: Connects to: Personality development (root in past), Therapeutic relationship building, Client insights

ARISTOTLE CONNECTION: Practical wisdom: Recognize that anger isn't about you personally. Help client develop self-knowledge (virtue of humility)

====================================================================================================

Q10. PRIMARY TOPIC: Social Welfare Concepts ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

FOLLOW-UP QUESTION: Why did Beveridge Report emphasize systemic welfare over charity? How does this relate to social justice?

ANSWER: Charity = discretionary, inconsistent, stigmatizing. Welfare = right-based, systematic, universal. Reflects justice principle of fairness.

TOPIC CONNECTIONS: Connects to: Social Work values, Professional ethics, Government responsibility

ARISTOTLE CONNECTION: Aristotle's distributive justice: Fair and systematic distribution. Welfare system = implementation of justice principle

====================================================================================================

Q11. PRIMARY TOPIC: Sociology: Social Institutions ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

FOLLOW-UP QUESTION: How do family kinship systems affect mental health and social support in Erikson's framework?

ANSWER: Extended kinship provides: Trust (Stage 1), Autonomy support (Stage 2), Industry opportunities (Stage 4), Intimate relationships (Stage 6)

TOPIC CONNECTIONS: Connects to: Erikson stages, Mental Health, Social Support importance

ARISTOTLE CONNECTION: Family as natural community. Kinship systems organized to develop human flourishing through stages

====================================================================================================

Q12. PRIMARY TOPIC: Cross-Topic Integration ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

FOLLOW-UP QUESTION: A woman has been abused as child (trauma), has poor self-esteem (normal in abuse), uses alcohol to cope (acting out). Is she abnormal?

ANSWER: Biopsychosocial: Normal response to abnormal situation. Trauma (biological/psychological damage), learned coping (defence mechanism), social consequences

TOPIC CONNECTIONS: ALL TOPICS: Combines trauma history, coping mechanisms, social context, therapeutic intervention needed

ARISTOTLE CONNECTION: Person capable of virtue but circumstances prevent flourishing. Therapy goal: Restore capacity to achieve eudaimonia

====================================================================================================

Q13. PRIMARY TOPIC: Cross-Topic Integration ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

FOLLOW-UP QUESTION: Design intervention for adolescent with identity confusion, poor family relationships, and isolation. Which methods/principles apply?

ANSWER: Casework (assess history), Group work (peer support), Community org (family/school involvement). Principles: Acceptance, self-determination, empowerment

TOPIC CONNECTIONS: ALL TOPICS: Erikson (Stage 5), Social work methods, Principles, Mental Health

ARISTOTLE CONNECTION: Practical wisdom in selecting integrated approach. Goal: Help adolescent develop identity and virtue

====================================================================================================

Q14. PRIMARY TOPIC: ARISTOTLE - Central Concept ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

FOLLOW-UP QUESTION: How do AIIMS PSW exam topics connect to Aristotle's philosophy of human flourishing (Eudaimonia)?

ANSWER: Personality development (Freud/Erikson) = path to character. Social institutions (family) = context. Mental health = capacity to flourish.

TOPIC CONNECTIONS: OVERARCHING: All topics are about helping humans achieve eudaimonia - their full potential

ARISTOTLE CONNECTION: Core: Virtue ethics. Virtues developed through: healthy relationships (family), resolving crises (Erikson), managing emotions (defence mechanisms), ethical practice (principles)

====================================================================================================

docs.title: AIIMS CRE Psychiatric Social Worker - Detailed Topic Study Guide
Simple Explanation
docs.text:
Freud believed that personality develops through 5 stages from birth to adulthood. At each stage, a different body part (erogenous zone) becomes the center of pleasure and conflict. If a person gets too much or too little gratification at a stage, they become "fixated" and develop specific personality traits.

The 5 Stages:

  1. ORAL STAGE (0-18 months)
  2. Focus: Mouth (eating, sucking, chewing)
  3. Task: Learn to trust caregivers

  4. Fixation Result: Oral-aggressive (aggressive, argumentative) or Oral-dependent (needy, dependent)

  5. ANAL STAGE (18 months - 3 years)

  6. Focus: Bowel/bladder control (toilet training)
  7. Task: Develop control and independence

  8. Fixation Result: Anal-retentive (perfectionist, orderly, stubborn) or Anal-expulsive (messy, rebellious)

  9. PHALLIC STAGE (3-6 years)

  10. Focus: Genitals, self-discovery
  11. Major Conflict: Oedipus complex (boys) / Electra complex (girls)
  12. Oedipus: Boy wants mother, competes with father, resolves by identifying with father
  13. Electra: Girl wants father, competes with mother, resolves by identifying with mother

  14. Penis Envy: Freud believed girls feel inferior for lacking penis

  15. LATENCY STAGE (6 years - puberty)

  16. Focus: Dormant sexual period
  17. Task: Develop skills, friendships, school learning

  18. Sexual energy sublimated into productive activities

  19. GENITAL STAGE (Puberty - adulthood)

  20. Focus: Mature sexual relationships
  21. Goal: Balance needs with adult responsibilities
  22. Healthy outcome: Mature, capable of love and work

docs.title: Most Asked Questions Pattern
docs.text:
• Which stage involves toilet training? (Anal Stage)
  • Oedipus complex occurs in which stage? (Phallic Stage)
  • What is latency period? (Sexual dormancy period)
  • Anal fixation leads to which traits? (Perfectionism, orderliness, stubbornness)
  • Who proposed psychosexual development? (Sigmund Freud)

docs.title: Key Terms to Remember
docs.text:
• Libido: Sexual/life energy that motivates behavior
  • Erogenous Zone: Body parts sensitive to pleasure
  • Fixation: Getting stuck at a stage due to unresolved conflict
  • Regression: Going back to earlier stage under stress
  • Sublimation: Channeling sexual energy into productive work

docs.title: Connection to Other Topics
docs.text:
→ Connect to ERIKSON'S THEORY - Both propose stage development - Erikson expanded Freud's approach to full lifespan - Erikson focused on social relationships; Freud on sexual drives

→ Connect to DEFENCE MECHANISMS - Fixations cause ego to use defence mechanisms - Anal fixation individuals use rationalization and reaction formation

→ Connect to NORMAL vs ABNORMAL BEHAVIOR - Severe fixations → neurotic symptoms - Understanding stage helps explain client's current behavior patterns

→ ARISTOTLE CONNECTION - Aristotle: Development = achieving virtue at each life stage - Freud: Development = resolving conflict at each psychosexual stage - Both: Childhood experiences shape adult character

docs.title: Simple Explanation
docs.text:
Erik Erikson built on Freud's work but made 3 major changes: 1. Extended development to ENTIRE LIFESPAN (not just childhood) 2. Focused on SOCIAL relationships, not sexual drives 3. Each stage has a CRISIS (challenge) that must be resolved

Each stage presents two opposite forces. Success at resolving them creates psychological strength; failure creates weakness.

The 8 Stages:

Stage Age Crisis Success Outcome Failure Outcome 1 0-18 months Trust vs Mistrust Hope, security Fear, anxiety 2 18 months-3 years Autonomy vs Shame/Doubt Will, independence Shame, self-doubt 3 3-5 years Initiative vs Guilt Purpose, confidence Guilt, inhibition 4 6 years-puberty Industry vs Inferiority Competence, skill Inferiority complex 5 12-18 years Identity vs Role Confusion Fidelity, identity Confusion, uncertainty 6 18-25 years Intimacy vs Isolation Love, relationships Loneliness, isolation 7 25-65 years Generativity vs Stagnation Care, contribution Selfishness, stagnation 8 65+ years Ego Integrity vs Despair Wisdom, acceptance Despair, regret

docs.title: Stage-by-Stage Explanation
docs.text:
Stage 1: TRUST vs MISTRUST (Infancy) - Baby depends completely on caregivers - If caregivers respond to needs: Baby develops trust, feels safe - If caregivers neglect: Baby develops mistrust, feels unsafe - For PSW: Understanding client's basic trust issues; impact of early neglect

Stage 4: INDUSTRY vs INFERIORITY (School Age) - Child learns skills through school and activities - Success → feels competent, worthy - Repeated failure → develops inferiority complex - For PSW: Why some children give up; importance of success experiences

Stage 5: IDENTITY vs ROLE CONFUSION (Adolescence) - Most critical for Psychiatric Social Work! - Adolescent asks: "Who am I? What do I believe? Where do I fit?" - Success → clear sense of identity, direction - Failure → identity confusion, unclear values, role confusion - For PSW: Reason for adolescent mental health issues; identity crisis common

Stage 6: INTIMACY vs ISOLATION (Young Adulthood) - Young adult seeks close relationships - Can only achieve intimacy after identity is formed (Stage 5) - Success → meaningful relationships, love - Failure → loneliness, isolation, fear of commitment

Stage 7: GENERATIVITY vs STAGNATION (Middle Adulthood) - Person contributes to next generation (children, work, mentoring) - Success → feels life has meaning, leaves legacy - Failure → feels life is pointless, self-centered - For PSW: Understand midlife crisis; importance of meaningful work

docs.title: Most Asked Questions
docs.text:
• Which stage involves "Who am I?" question? (Stage 5: Adolescence)
  • Trust vs Mistrust develops in which stage? (Stage 1: Infancy)
  • Intimacy vs Isolation is in which stage? (Stage 6: Young Adulthood)
  • How many stages in Erikson's theory? (8 stages)
  • What is generativity? (Contributing to next generation)

docs.title: Connection to Other Topics
docs.text:
→ Connect to FREUD'S THEORY - Erikson based on Freud but extended it - Erikson less focus on sexual drives, more on social needs - Both: Early experiences matter; stage-based development

→ Connect to ATTACHMENT THEORY - Trust vs Mistrust = Secure vs Insecure attachment - Early bonding affects later relationships

→ Connect to MENTAL HEALTH - Erikson's framework explains common mental health issues - Identity confusion → depression, anxiety in adolescents - Lack of generativity → midlife depression

→ ARISTOTLE CONNECTION - Aristotle: "We are what we repeatedly do" - Erikson: Repeated experiences at each stage shape personality - Both: Development = gradual formation of character

docs.title: TOPIC 3: MENTAL HEALTH & MENTAL HYGIENE CONCEPTS
Simple Explanation
docs.text:
MENTAL HEALTH (WHO Definition): "A state of mental well-being in which an individual realizes their abilities, can cope with normal life stresses, can work productively, and contribute to their community."

KEY POINT: Mental health ≠ Just "no mental illness" - It's POSITIVE state, not just absence of disease - It's a SPECTRUM (not black/white) - It includes: emotional, psychological, social well-being

MENTAL HYGIENE: Similar to PHYSICAL hygiene (brushing teeth, bathing), mental hygiene is proactive care to maintain mental health and prevent mental illness.

docs.title: The 3 Pillars of Mental Health
docs.text:
1. EMOTIONAL WELL-BEING
  2. Understanding and managing emotions
  3. Resilience under stress

  4. Life satisfaction

  5. PSYCHOLOGICAL WELL-BEING

  6. Self-actualization and personal growth
  7. Meaning and purpose

  8. Autonomy and decision-making

  9. SOCIAL WELL-BEING

  10. Quality relationships
  11. Social support
  12. Community contribution
  13. Social inclusion

docs.title: Mental Hygiene Principles (Prevention)
docs.text:
Physical Health Foundation: - Adequate sleep (7-9 hours) - Proper nutrition - Regular physical exercise - Limit alcohol, avoid drugs

Psychological Practices: - Stress management techniques (meditation, breathing) - Mindfulness - Mental retraining (positive thinking) - Regular self-reflection

Social Practices: - Maintain close relationships - Join community groups - Help others (volunteering) - Seek social support

Professional Care: - Regular check-ups with mental health professionals - Early intervention if symptoms appear - Counseling/therapy when needed

docs.title: Characteristics of Mental Health
docs.text: ✓ Realistic perception of reality ✓ Ability to control impulses ✓ Effective coping with stress ✓ Good self-esteem ✓ Ability to love and form relationships ✓ Productive work and learning ✓ Sense of purpose and meaning

docs.title: Most Asked Questions
docs.text:
• What is WHO definition of mental health? (State of well-being where individual realizes abilities)
  • Is mental health just absence of mental illness? (No, it's positive state)
  • Name one mental hygiene principle? (Sleep, nutrition, exercise, relationships, etc.)
  • What are 3 pillars of mental health? (Emotional, Psychological, Social)
  • Mental hygiene aims to what? (Promote mental health and prevent illness)

docs.title: Connection to Other Topics
docs.text:
→ Connect to PERSONALITY THEORIES - Personality affects mental health outcomes - Erikson's successful development → better mental health

→ Connect to NORMAL vs ABNORMAL BEHAVIOR - Mental health exists on CONTINUUM - Most people experience mental health challenges sometimes

→ Connect to SOCIAL SUPPORT - Social relationships crucial for mental health - Isolation → mental health problems

→ Connect to MENTAL HEALTH PROGRAMS (DMHP, MHCA) - Implementation of mental health promotion - Government schemes supporting mental hygiene

→ ARISTOTLE CONNECTION - Aristotle's "Eudaimonia" (Human Flourishing) = Modern Mental Health concept - Both emphasize realizing human potential and living well - Both require developing virtues and good character

docs.title: TOPIC 4: SOCIAL WORK METHODS: CASEWORK, GROUP WORK, COMMUNITY ORGANIZATION
Simple Explanation
docs.text:
Social workers use different methods (ways) to help. Think of it like a doctor using different treatments for different patients.

PRIMARY METHODS (Direct work with people): 1. Case Work (1-on-1) 2. Group Work (Groups) 3. Community Organization (Community level)

SECONDARY METHODS (Supporting/Administrative): 1. Social Welfare Administration 2. Social Work Research 3. Social Action

docs.title: METHOD 1: CASE WORK (Individual/Family Work)
docs.text:
What is it? One-on-one helping relationship between social worker and client (or family).

Process (4 Steps): 1. Assessment - Understand client's problems, strengths, resources 2. Planning - Set goals with client 3. Intervention - Take action to solve problems 4. Evaluation - Check if goals achieved

Tools Used: - Interviews and listening - Building trust - Problem-solving - Counseling - Resource linking

Types of Case Work: - Individual Casework: One person - Family Casework: Whole family unit (domestic violence, parenting issues, family conflict) - Group Casework: Multiple individuals with similar problems in group setting

Example: A psychiatric social worker helps a person with depression: assess triggers, plan treatment, refer to psychiatrist, follow-up to ensure improvement.

docs.title: METHOD 2: GROUP WORK
docs.text:
What is it? Using group dynamics (power of group) to help individuals improve, learn, and support each other.

Principle: "Strength in numbers" - People help each other in group setting.

Types of Groups:

  1. Therapeutic Groups
  2. Purpose: Healing and growth
  3. Example: Group therapy for trauma survivors

  4. Facilitator: Social worker guides but doesn't direct

  5. Support Groups

  6. Purpose: Mutual support for common issues
  7. Example: Cancer survivor support group, grief support group

  8. Facilitator: Often peer-led, social worker coordinates

  9. Skill-Building Groups

  10. Purpose: Learn specific skills
  11. Example: Anger management group, parenting skills group

  12. Facilitator: Social worker teaches specific skills

  13. Educational Groups

  14. Purpose: Share information
  15. Example: Mental health awareness group
  16. Facilitator: Social worker provides education

Benefits of Group Work: - Reduced isolation (realize "I'm not alone") - Peer learning - Social skills practice - Cost-effective - Empowerment through mutual help

docs.title: METHOD 3: COMMUNITY ORGANIZATION
docs.text:
What is it? Organizing communities to identify problems, plan solutions, and take collective action.

Goal: Sustainable social change through community participation.

Process: 1. Community Assessment - Understand community needs 2. Awareness Building - Educate community about issues 3. Mobilization - Encourage participation 4. Action - Take collective steps 5. Sustainability - Maintain changes

Tools: - Community meetings - Focus group discussions - Participatory Rural Appraisal (PRA) - Advocacy campaigns - Capacity building - Network development

Example: PSW organizing community meeting to discuss mental health stigma, planning awareness campaign, mobilizing community leaders, conducting workshops.

docs.title: Simple Explanation
docs.text:
When facing stressful or threatening situations, our mind uses defence mechanisms - automatic, unconscious tricks to protect our ego (self-image) from anxiety.

Key Point: Defence mechanisms are NOT conscious; we don't realize we're using them.

docs.title: The 3 Levels of Defence Mechanisms
docs.text:
LEVEL 1: IMMATURE DEFENCES (Used by children and adults under stress)

  1. PROJECTION
  2. What: Attributing own unacceptable feelings to others
  3. Example: "I'm not angry at you, YOU are angry at me"

  4. Real Situation: Aggressive person accuses others of being aggressive

  5. DISPLACEMENT

  6. What: Expressing feelings toward safe target instead of real target
  7. Example: Boss criticizes you at work; you go home and yell at spouse

  8. Real Situation: Moving emotional reaction from real source to substitute

  9. ACTING OUT

  10. What: Expressing unconscious impulses through actions instead of words
  11. Example: Angry person punches wall instead of talking about anger

  12. Real Situation: Physical expression of emotions instead of verbal

  13. REGRESSION

  14. What: Going back to earlier, childish behaviors
  15. Example: Adult sucking thumb when stressed; reverting to childlike speech

  16. Real Situation: Under extreme stress, acting younger than actual age

  17. IDENTIFICATION

  18. What: Adopting characteristics of someone else to reduce anxiety
  19. Example: Abused child copying abuser's behavior
  20. Real Situation: Incorporating another's traits into own personality

LEVEL 2: NEUROTIC DEFENCES (Used by most people sometimes)

  1. REPRESSION
  2. What: Pushing threatening memories into unconscious
  3. Example: Childhood abuse victim "forgetting" the abuse
  4. Real Situation: Can't remember event even though it happened

  5. Note: Different from SUPPRESSION (conscious forgetting)

  6. RATIONALIZATION

  7. What: Creating logical explanations for illogical feelings/behaviors
  8. Example: "I'm late because traffic was bad" (when really you overslept)

  9. Real Situation: Justifying behavior with false reasoning

  10. INTELLECTUALIZATION

  11. What: Discussing emotional topics in detached, intellectual way
  12. Example: Person discussing death of loved one without any emotion

  13. Real Situation: Avoiding emotional pain through intellectual analysis

  14. REACTION FORMATION

  15. What: Expressing opposite of what you truly feel
  16. Example: Overly nice to person you actually hate
  17. Real Situation: Masking true emotion with opposite emotion

LEVEL 3: MATURE DEFENCES (Adaptive, healthy; used by psychologically healthy people)

  1. SUBLIMATION
  2. What: Channeling negative emotions/energy into productive activities
  3. Example: Processing anger through sports, art, music, or work
  4. Real Situation: Converting emotional pain into creative output

  5. Most Healthy Defence: Acknowledged and studied extensively

  6. HUMOUR (Appropriate, not hurtful)

  7. What: Using humor to cope with stress without hurting others
  8. Example: Making light joke about your own mistake
  9. Real Situation: Laugh at situation to reduce tension

  10. Not: Making fun of others or cruel jokes

  11. SUPPRESSION

  12. What: Consciously postponing dealing with impulses/conflicts
  13. Example: "I'm upset about something but I'll talk about it after the meeting"

  14. Real Situation: Conscious decision to delay processing emotion

  15. ALTRUISM

  16. What: Helping others to work through own conflicts
  17. Example: Working with homeless population after own difficult period

  18. Real Situation: Turning own suffering into service

  19. ANTICIPATION

  20. What: Realistic planning for future challenges
  21. Example: Worrying about exam so you study hard
  22. Real Situation: Anxiety motivates preparation

docs.title: Simple Explanation
docs.text:
Question: When is behavior "abnormal"?

Answer: When it's MALADAPTIVE, causes DISTRESS, and violates SOCIAL NORMS.

Key Point: No single criterion defines abnormality. Use MULTIPLE PERSPECTIVES.

docs.title: 4 Criteria for Defining Abnormality
docs.text: Criterion Description Limitation Statistical Rarity Behavior is statistically unusual/rare Genius-level intelligence is rare but normal Personal Distress Behavior causes suffering to person Some disturbed people don't feel distressed Violation of Social Norms Behavior breaks social rules Social norms vary by culture and time Maladaptation/Dysfunction Behavior prevents functioning What counts as dysfunction varies

docs.title: Three Models of Abnormality
docs.text:
MODEL 1: MEDICAL MODEL - View: Abnormality = mental illness = brain disease - Cause: Biological (genetic, neurochemical) - Treatment: Medical (drugs, hospitalization) - Problem: Ignores psychological and social factors

MODEL 2: PSYCHOLOGICAL MODEL - View: Abnormality = learned maladaptive behavior or thought patterns - Cause: Past experiences, trauma, learned associations - Treatment: Therapy, counseling, behavior modification - Problem: Ignores biological and social factors

MODEL 3: SOCIAL MODEL - View: Abnormality = failure to adapt to society's expectations - Cause: Social factors (poverty, discrimination, stress) - Treatment: Social change, environmental modifications - Problem: May ignore individual pathology

docs.title: BIOPSYCHOSOCIAL MODEL (Recommended approach)
docs.text:
Integrated Model considering all three factors:

Biological Factors
(genetics, brain chemistry, neurotransmitters)
          ↓
     ↙    ↓    ↘
Psychological ← ABNORMALITY → Social Factors
Factors               (environment, culture,
(trauma, beliefs,      socioeconomic, relationships)
learning)

Example - Depression: - Biological: Low serotonin - Psychological: Negative thought patterns, past trauma - Social: Unemployment, relationship problems, isolation

Treatment: Combination of medication (biological), therapy (psychological), social support (social).

docs.title: Examples of Normal Behavior That Might Seem Abnormal
docs.text:
• Grief after loss: Sad, withdrawn, crying = NORMAL (not depression unless severe)
  • Anxiety before exam: Nervous, worried = NORMAL
  • Shyness: Introversion, social anxiety = NORMAL (unless severe social phobia)
  • Belief Systems: Religious practices, cultural rituals = NORMAL if culturally appropriate

docs.title: Examples of Abnormal Behavior
docs.text:
• Hallucinations: Hearing voices others can't hear + causes distress = ABNORMAL
  • Delusions: Believing things against all evidence = ABNORMAL
  • Compulsions: Uncontrollable repetitive behaviors = ABNORMAL
  • Parasuicidal: Self-harm to cope = ABNORMAL

docs.text:
1. Clinical Interview: Professional conversation
  2. Psychological Tests: IQ tests, personality tests
  3. Medical Tests: Blood tests, brain imaging
  4. Social Assessment: Family, work, social functioning
  5. DSM-5 / ICD-11: Diagnostic manuals

docs.text:

docs.title: TOPIC 7: SOCIAL WORK PRINCIPLES & PROFESSIONAL VALUES
Simple Explanation
docs.text:
Principles are the FUNDAMENTAL GUIDELINES that govern ALL social work practice, regardless of method or setting.

Think of them like the "rules" of ethical practice that social workers must follow.

docs.title: 7 Core Principles of Social Work
docs.text:
1. PRINCIPLE OF INDIVIDUALIZATION

What: Treat each client as unique person; no two cases are identical.

How to Apply: - Assess unique factors: age, culture, beliefs, abilities, challenges - Don't use "one-size-fits-all" solutions - Tailor intervention to specific client - Recognize individual differences despite similar presenting problems

Example: Two clients with depression may need different approaches - Client A: Needs medication + cognitive therapy - Client B: Needs counseling + social support + job training

2. PRINCIPLE OF PURPOSEFUL EXPRESSION

What: Create conditions where client can freely express thoughts, feelings, and concerns.

How to Apply: - Active listening without interruption - Create safe, non-judgmental environment - Ask open-ended questions - Respect client's pace of sharing - Use body language showing interest

Example: Let client tell their story fully before offering advice; don't rush or interrupt.

3. PRINCIPLE OF CONTROLLED EMOTIONAL INVOLVEMENT

What: Show empathy and caring WITHOUT losing objectivity and professional boundaries.

How to Apply: - Empathy ≠ Sympathy (understand vs feel sorry for) - Maintain professional distance - Be warm but not personal friends - Manage counter-transference - Know when to refer to another worker if too emotionally involved

Tricky Balance: Care about client BUT don't get too involved that judgment becomes clouded.

Example: "I understand this is painful for you" (empathy) vs "That's terrible, I feel so sad for you" (too much sympathy).

4. PRINCIPLE OF ACCEPTANCE

What: Respect client's worth and dignity REGARDLESS of personal views about their behavior/beliefs.

How to Apply: - Separate person from behavior - Accept client even if you disagree with actions - Don't judge or moralize - Create safe space where client feels valued - Accept client's pace of change

NOT Condoning: You accept the person but may not accept all behaviors.

Example: Client is ex-convict or sex worker. Accept them as worthy person even if you don't approve of past actions.

5. PRINCIPLE OF NON-JUDGMENTAL ATTITUDE

What: Set aside personal biases, prejudices, and moral judgments in assessment and treatment.

How to Apply: - Be aware of own biases - Actively work to suspend judgment - Assess objectively based on facts - Respect diverse values and beliefs - Recognize cultural differences - Don't impose own values

Hardest Principle: Requires ongoing self-awareness and reflection.

Example: Client believes in arranged marriage. Even if you prefer love marriage, don't judge or criticize their choice.

6. PRINCIPLE OF CONFIDENTIALITY

What: Protect client's privacy. Information shared in professional relationship is confidential.

How to Apply: - Keep client information private - Don't gossip or share unnecessarily - Write records securely - Seek permission before sharing - Know exceptions: Risk of harm, abuse, court orders, breaking law

Important Exception: If client is danger to self/others or there's abuse, MUST breach confidentiality.

Example: Client tells you about suicidal plans. Must inform psychiatrist/family despite confidentiality principle.

7. PRINCIPLE OF SELF-DETERMINATION

What: Respect client's right to make own decisions about their life.

How to Apply: - Provide information about options - Support client's choices (even if you disagree) - Don't impose solutions - Client drives pace and goals of intervention - Recognize client's autonomy

Limit: When choice causes harm (endangering self/others), may need to limit self-determination.

Example: Client decides to leave husband. Even if you think she should stay, support her decision if it's her choice.

docs.title: Core Professional Values
docs.text:
1. HUMAN DIGNITY - Every person has worth - Respect for all human beings

2. SOCIAL JUSTICE - Fair treatment regardless of status - Advocacy for oppressed/vulnerable - Challenge systemic inequalities

3. RESPECT FOR DIVERSITY - Cultural competence - Respecting different beliefs, backgrounds - Non-discrimination

4. EMPOWERMENT - Enable clients to take control of life - Develop strengths and capacities - Reduce dependency

5. COMMITMENT TO SERVICE - Dedication to helping - Going beyond minimum requirements - Putting client needs first

docs.title: Simple Explanation
docs.text:
TRANSFERENCE: Client's emotional reaction to therapist BASED ON PAST RELATIONSHIPS, not based on therapist's actual behavior.

COUNTER-TRANSFERENCE: Therapist's emotional reaction to client.

Both are NORMAL, EXPECTED, and therapeutically USEFUL if recognized and managed.

docs.title: TRANSFERENCE in Detail
docs.text:
What is Transference?

Client projects feelings, attitudes, expectations from past relationships (especially parents/authority figures) ONTO the therapist/social worker.

Key Point: It's about CLIENT'S PAST, not about therapist's actual behavior.

Common Transference Patterns:

  1. Paternal/Maternal Transference
  2. Client treats worker like parent
  3. Seeks approval/disapproval like child

  4. Example: Adult client seeking validation from worker like seeking from parent

  5. Romantic Transference

  6. Client develops attraction or romantic feelings
  7. Based on client's needs, not real relationship

  8. Example: Client idealizing worker, wanting closer relationship

  9. Negative Transference

  10. Client becomes angry, resistant, suspicious
  11. Transfers past negative experiences onto worker

  12. Example: Client antagonistic if worker reminds them of authority figure who hurt them

  13. Authoritative Transference

  14. Client sees worker as expert/authority
  15. Complies or resists against authority
  16. Example: Client follows all advice unthinkingly or rebels against all suggestions

docs.title: COUNTER-TRANSFERENCE in Detail
docs.text:
What is Counter-transference?

Therapist's emotional and behavioral responses to client, including: - Feelings (attraction, anger, boredom) - Reactions (wanting to rescue, becoming punitive) - Biases triggered by client

Why Counter-transference Happens? - Therapist is human with own issues - Client reminds therapist of someone from their past - Client's behavior triggers therapist's vulnerabilities

Examples of Counter-transference: - Therapist attracted to client - Therapist overprotective of vulnerable client - Therapist impatient with demanding client - Therapist identifying too much with client's struggles - Therapist avoiding certain clients

docs.title: How to Manage Transference & Counter-transference
docs.text:
Steps to Manage TRANSFERENCE:

  1. RECOGNIZE IT
  2. Notice unusual emotional reactions from client
  3. Client's behavior inconsistent with situation

  4. Patterns emerging

  5. UNDERSTAND IT

  6. Where is this coming from?
  7. What past experience is being repeated?

  8. What need is client expressing?

  9. USE IT THERAPEUTICALLY

  10. Gently point out pattern: "I notice you seem angry with me like..."
  11. Help client understand connection to past

  12. Insight → Change in patterns

  13. DON'T ACT ON IT

  14. Don't reciprocate romantic transference
  15. Don't become the idealized parent
  16. Maintain professional boundaries
  17. Don't collude with resistance

Steps to Manage COUNTER-TRANSFERENCE:

  1. RECOGNIZE YOUR FEELINGS
  2. Be aware of emotional reactions
  3. Identify what specifically triggers you

  4. Don't act immediately

  5. REFLECT ON SOURCE

  6. Why does this client trigger me?
  7. What do they remind me of?

  8. What's MY issue here?

  9. MANAGE IT PROFESSIONALLY

  10. Don't let feelings guide your treatment
  11. Maintain objectivity
  12. Seek supervision if needed

  13. Sometimes refer to another worker if too involved

  14. USE IT FOR UNDERSTANDING

  15. Counter-transference can provide insight into client
  16. If you feel rejected, maybe client rejects others too
  17. Clues about client's impact on relationships

docs.title: Examples Showing Both
docs.text:
Scenario: Female client with absent father meets male social worker.

Client's Transference (to worker): - Seeks approval/attention - Tests if he'll abandon her like father - Initially idealized; later disappointed - Angry or withdrawn if he doesn't respond emotionally

Worker's Counter-transference (to client): - Feels protective/parental - Wants to "fix" her father issues - Gets frustrated if she doesn't improve - Notices he looks forward to her sessions

Healthy Management: - Worker recognizes patterns - Helps client see: "You seem to want approval from me like you wanted from father" - Worker maintains professional boundaries - Supports client's healing of father relationship

  • Should therapist act on counter-transference? (No, must recognize and manage it)

docs.title: Social Welfare and Social Work
docs.text:
Question 1: What is the primary goal of social work? A. To provide therapy and counseling services. B. To advocate for social justice and equality. C. To administer government programs and policies. D. To conduct research on social issues.

Answer: B. To advocate for social justice and equality.

Question 2: What is the person-in-environment perspective in social work? A. The understanding that individuals are influenced by their social and physical environments. B. The focus on individual thoughts and feelings in therapy sessions. C. The belief that individuals are solely responsible for their own well-being. D. The emphasis on personal growth and self-actualization.

Answer: A. The understanding that individuals are influenced by their social and physical environments.

Question 3: Which of the following is an example of micro-level social work practice? A. Community organizing and development. B. Policy analysis and advocacy. C. Individual counseling and therapy. D. Program evaluation and research.

Answer: C. Individual counseling and therapy.

Question 4: What is the purpose of the social work code of ethics? A. To provide guidelines for ethical decision-making and professional conduct. B. To regulate and license social work practitioners. C. To ensure compliance with government regulations and policies. D. To conduct research on social issues.

Answer: A. To provide guidelines for ethical decision-making and professional conduct.

Question 5: What is the role of a social worker in case management? A. To diagnose and treat mental health disorders. B. To provide financial assistance and resources to individuals and families. C. To coordinate and monitor services to meet the needs of clients. D. To conduct research and evaluation studies on social issues.

Answer: C. To coordinate and monitor services to meet the needs of clients.

docs.title: Professional Social Work
docs.text:
Question 1: A therapist is meeting with a client for an initial evaluation. The client reports feeling moody and has been having many headaches. The client states that she lost a lot of weight recently and has noticed a decrease in appetite. The clinician should FIRST: A. Assess the client for suicidality. B. Refer the client to a psychiatrist. C. Complete a mental status exam. D. Refer the client to a Medical Doctor (MD).

Answer: D. Refer the client to a MD.

Question 2: A social worker in a psychiatric setting is working with a client who exhibits characteristics of Bipolar I Disorder. The psychiatrist in the clinic plans to prescribe medication for the client. Which of the following is the most commonly used medication for Bipolar I Disorder? A. Lithium B. Ritalin C. Zoloft D. Prozac

Answer: A. Lithium.

Question 3: During Mrs. S's first appointment in a family agency, the social worker encourages her to express her feelings about the recent placement of her child in a residential facility for the developmentally disabled. Mrs. S talks at length instead about her physical health problems. The social worker should: A. use Mrs. S's remarks about her health to identify unresolved parenting issues. B. refocus the interview on the child's behavior and the reason for the residential placement. C. explore with Mrs. S how her health problems are related to the recent placement of her child. D. listen to Mrs. S's description of her health as a beginning of a relationship and means of assessing her self-perception.

Answer: D. listen to Mrs. S's description of her health as a beginning of a relationship and means of assessing her self-perception.

docs.title: Psychology & Mental Health
docs.text:
Question 1: A college student has made an appointment to speak with a counselor at her university's counseling center about troublesome symptoms she has experienced on a number of occasions over the last six months. The symptoms include chest pain, nausea, pounding heart, and dizziness. A recent medical exam failed to identify any physical problems. Which of the following DSM-5 diagnoses is this student MOST LIKELY suffering from? A) Generalized Anxiety Disorder B) Social Anxiety Disorder C) Panic Disorder D) Specific Phobia

Answer: C) Panic Disorder.

Question 2: What is the primary role of a psychiatric social worker? A) Conducting psychological assessments B) Providing mental health services to individuals and families C) Prescribing medication D) Performing surgical procedures

Answer: B) Providing mental health services to individuals and families.

Question 3: What is the difference between delusions and hallucinations when a social worker is making an assessment with a client presenting with psychiatric issues? A. Delusions are false, fixed beliefs despite evidence to the contrary, while hallucinations are hearing, seeing, smelling, or feeling something that is not real. B. Hallucinations are false, fixed beliefs despite evidence to the contrary, while delusions are hearing, seeing, smelling, or feeling something that is not real. C. Delusions and hallucinations are both types of thought disorders. D. Delusions are always persecutory, while hallucinations are always auditory.

Answer: A. Delusions are false, fixed beliefs despite evidence to the contrary, while hallucinations are hearing, seeing, smelling, or feeling something that is not real.

docs.title: Sociology
docs.text:
Question 1: Which sociological perspective emphasizes the role of power, inequality, and conflict in shaping society and mental health outcomes? a) Functionalism b) Symbolic Interactionism c) Conflict Theory d) Social Exchange Theory

Answer: c) Conflict Theory

Question 2: The concept of "stigma" in sociology, particularly concerning mental illness, refers to: a) A biological marker indicating a predisposition to mental illness. b) A deeply discrediting attribute that reduces a person from a whole and usual person to a tainted, discounted one. c) A legal term used to describe individuals deemed incompetent due to mental health issues. d) A therapeutic technique used to challenge negative thought patterns.

Answer: b) A deeply discrediting attribute that reduces a person from a whole and usual person to a tainted, discounted one.

Question 3: Emile Durkheim's study of suicide highlighted the importance of which sociological factor? a) Economic recession b) Individual psychological disorders c) Social integration and regulation d) Genetic inheritance

Answer: c) Social integration and regulation

docs.title: Social Psychology
docs.text:
Question 1: Which of the following best describes the concept of "social loafing"? A) An individual's tendency to exert less effort when working in a group than when working alone. B) The enhancement of a group's prevailing inclinations through discussion within the group. C) The loss of self-awareness and self-restraint occurring in group situations that foster arousal and anonymity. D) A mode of thinking that persons engage in when concurrence-seeking becomes so dominant in a cohesive in-group that it tends to override realistic appraisal of alternative courses of action.

Answer: A) An individual's tendency to exert less effort when working in a group than when working alone.

Question 2: The "fundamental attribution error" refers to the tendency for observers to: A) Underestimate the impact of situational factors and overestimate the impact of dispositional factors when explaining others' behavior. B) Overestimate the impact of situational factors and underestimate the impact of dispositional factors when explaining others' behavior. C) Attribute their own successes to internal factors and their failures to external factors. D) Attribute others' successes to external factors and their failures to internal factors.

Answer: A) Underestimate the impact of situational factors and overestimate the impact of dispositional factors when explaining others' behavior.

docs.title: What is AIIMS?
docs.text:
The All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) is a group of autonomous government public medical universities of higher education. It was established in 1956 through an Act of Parliament and is governed by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. AIIMS, New Delhi, is the parent institution and is consistently ranked as the top medical college in India.

Key Features of AIIMS: * Mission: To provide high-quality patient care, train medical and paramedical professionals, and conduct advanced research. * Structure: AIIMS institutions are designated as "Institutions of National Importance." They have a tripartite mission of teaching, research, and patient care. * Autonomy: They are autonomous bodies, which allows them to have their own curriculum, standards, and operational policies, ensuring a high standard of excellence. * Network: From one institution in New Delhi, AIIMS has expanded to numerous locations across India, including Bhopal, Bhubaneswar, Jodhpur, Patna, Raipur, and Rishikesh, among others.

docs.title: What is the AIIMS Common Recruitment Examination (CRE)?
docs.text:
The AIIMS Common Recruitment Examination (CRE) is a centralized, computer-based test conducted by AIIMS, New Delhi, for filling various Group B and C non-medical posts across all AIIMS institutions. The primary goal of CRE is to streamline the recruitment process, making it efficient, transparent, and standardized.

Diagram: The AIIMS CRE Process (Explained in Words)

  1. Central Notification: AIIMS, New Delhi, releases a single advertisement for multiple posts across various AIIMS locations.
  2. Common Application: Candidates fill out one application form, choosing their preferred posts and AIIMS locations.
  3. Standardized Examination: All candidates for a specific post appear for the same examination paper, ensuring a level playing field.
  4. Merit-Based Allocation: Based on the rank obtained in the CRE and the preferences submitted, candidates are allocated to different AIIMS institutions.

This system simplifies the process for applicants who would otherwise have to apply separately to each AIIMS.

docs.title: The Role of a Psychiatric Social Worker at AIIMS
docs.text:
A Psychiatric Social Worker (PSW) is a vital member of the multidisciplinary mental health team. At an institution like AIIMS, the role is demanding and requires a high degree of professional competence. The PSW serves as a bridge between the patient, their family, and the medical team.

Core Responsibilities:

Responsibility Area Specific Tasks Psychosocial Assessment Conducting detailed interviews with patients and families to gather information about their social, economic, and emotional background. Identifying stressors and support systems. Counselling & Therapy Providing individual, group, and family therapy. Using therapeutic techniques to help patients cope with their illness and improve functioning. Case Management Coordinating with doctors, nurses, psychologists, and occupational therapists to create a comprehensive care plan. Community Linkages Connecting patients and families with community resources, such as rehabilitation centers, vocational training programs, and government welfare schemes. Advocacy Advocating for the rights of patients with mental illness and working to reduce stigma. Documentation Maintaining detailed and confidential records of all patient interactions and interventions.

The role requires a strong foundation in social work principles, psychological theories, and an understanding of the mental health legal framework in India.

docs.title: Real-life Examples or Case Applications
docs.text:
Case Scenario: A 25-year-old male patient is admitted to the psychiatry ward at AIIMS with a diagnosis of schizophrenia. He has lost his job and his family is distressed.

  • PSW's Intervention:
    1. Assessment: The PSW meets the family to understand their financial situation, their understanding of the illness, and the level of support they can provide.
    2. Psychoeducation: The PSW conducts sessions with the family to educate them about schizophrenia, the importance of medication adherence, and how to manage challenging behaviors.
    3. Counselling: The PSW provides supportive counselling to the patient to help him deal with the emotional turmoil of his diagnosis and job loss.
    4. Resource Mobilization: The PSW connects the family with a local NGO that provides vocational training for persons with mental illness and informs them about the disability pension scheme.
    5. Discharge Planning: Before discharge, the PSW works with the family and the patient to create a relapse prevention plan.

This case illustrates how a PSW's role extends beyond the hospital to ensure the patient's successful reintegration into the community.

docs.title: Part 1: Analogies
docs.text:
An analogy is a form of reasoning where a relationship between two items is established, and the same relationship is then used to find a missing item in another pair. The goal is to identify the underlying logic connecting the first pair.

The standard format is A : B :: C : ? This is read as: "A is to B as C is to [what?]"

docs.title: Types of Word-Based Analogies
docs.text:
Understanding these common relationships is the key to solving analogy problems.

Relationship Type Example Explanation Cause and Effect Virus : Disease A virus is the cause of a disease. Part to Whole Chapter : Book A chapter is a part of a whole book. Worker and Tool Surgeon : Scalpel A surgeon uses a scalpel as their tool. Object and Category Whale : Mammal A whale belongs to the mammal category. Synonyms/Antonyms Abundant : Plentiful These words are synonyms (have the same meaning). Intensity Warm : Hot Hot is a higher intensity of warm. Symbol and Meaning Dove : Peace A dove is a symbol of peace. Country and Capital Japan : Tokyo Tokyo is the capital of Japan. Product and Raw Material Cloth : Fibre Cloth is made from fibre.

docs.title: How to Solve Analogy Questions
docs.text:
1. Decode the Relationship: First, precisely identify the relationship between the first pair (A and B). Be specific. "Surgeon : Scalpel" isn't just about medicine; it's about a professional and their specific tool.
  2. State the Relationship: Form a clear sentence. "A surgeon uses a scalpel."
  3. Apply to the Second Pair: Apply the same sentence structure to the second item (C). "A sculptor uses a [what?]."
  4. Find the Match: The answer would be "Chisel."

docs.title: Number and Letter Analogies
docs.text:
• Number Analogies: These are based on mathematical operations.
    • Example: 8 : 64 :: 9 : ?
    • Logic: The relationship is x : x². So, 8² is 64.
    • Answer: 9² is 81.
  • Letter Analogies: These are based on the position or sequence of letters in the alphabet.
    • Example: ACE : GIK :: BDF : ?
    • Logic: Each letter in the first group is skipped by one (ACE). The second group starts after skipping one letter from the end of the first group (EG). The same pattern (BD_F) applies.
    • Answer: HJL (skip one letter after F, which is G, start with H).

docs.title: Part 2: Classification (Odd One Out)
docs.text: Classification questions present a group of four or five items. All but one of these items are similar to one another in some way. Your task is to identify the item that does not fit the group.

docs.title: Types of Classification
docs.text:
• Word Classification: Based on a common property of words (e.g., meaning, category).
    • Example: A. Lion, B. Tiger, C. Leopard, D. Cow
    • Logic: Lion, Tiger, and Leopard are carnivores and wild cats. A cow is a domestic herbivore.
    • Answer: Cow.
  • Number Classification: Based on a common mathematical property.
    • Example: A. 25, B. 49, C. 81, D. 65
    • Logic: 25 (5²), 49 (7²), and 81 (9²) are perfect squares. 65 is not.
    • Answer: 65.
  • Letter Classification: Based on patterns in letter groups (vowels, consonants, sequence).
    • Example: A. IO, B. EA, C. OU, D. UP
    • Logic: IO, EA, and OU are pairs of vowels. UP contains a consonant.
    • Answer: UP.

docs.title: AIIMS CRE-Oriented Tips & Tricks
docs.text:
• Build General Knowledge: Word analogies often depend on your vocabulary and general awareness. Regularly read and learn about countries, capitals, currencies, and scientific facts.
  • Master the Alphabet: For letter-based questions, memorize the numerical position of each letter (A=1, B=2...) and its reverse position (Z=1, Y=2...). The "EJOTY" (5, 10, 15, 20, 25) and "V" (22) trick can help you quickly locate letter positions.
  • Sharpen Math Skills: For number-based questions, be quick with squares, cubes, prime numbers, and basic arithmetic operations.
  • Think Broadly, then Narrowly: In classification, first look for a very obvious similarity. If none exists, look for more subtle connections. For example, all might be animals, but three might be mammals while one is a reptile.
  • Eliminate Options: In analogies, if you are unsure, try to eliminate options that have a clearly incorrect relationship.

docs.title: Detailed Theory / Concepts
docs.text: A series is a sequence of numbers, letters, or figures arranged in a specific order according to a certain, definite rule. Your task is to identify this rule and use it to find a missing term or the next term in the sequence.

docs.title: 1. Number Series
docs.text:
This is the most common type of series question. The relationship between numbers can be based on various arithmetic operations.

How to Approach Number Series: 1. Check the Differences: Calculate the difference between consecutive numbers. 2. Is the difference constant? It's an Arithmetic Series. * Example: 5, 9, 13, 17, ? (Difference is a constant +4). Answer: 21. 3. Is the difference not constant? Check the differences of the differences (Double Difference Series). * Example: 1, 2, 5, 10, 17, ? * Differences: 1, 3, 5, 7. (This new series has a constant difference of +2). The next difference will be 9. * Answer: 17 + 9 = 26. 4. Check the Ratio: If the numbers are increasing or decreasing rapidly, check the ratio. 5. Is the ratio constant? It's a Geometric Series. * Example: 2, 6, 18, 54, ? (Ratio is a constant x3). Answer: 162. 6. Check for Squares and Cubes: Look for numbers that are perfect squares (1, 4, 9, 16...) or cubes (1, 8, 27, 64...). The pattern could be n², n³, n²+1, n²-1, etc. * Example: 0, 3, 8, 15, 24, ? * Logic: This is an n²-1 series (1²-1, 2²-1, 3²-1, 4²-1, 5²-1). The next term is 6²-1. * Answer: 35. 7. Look for a Mixed Series: The series might be a combination of two or more independent series. * Example: 1, 8, 2, 10, 3, 12, ? * Logic: Two alternating series: (1, 2, 3, ...) and (8, 10, 12, ...). The next term is from the first series. * Answer: 4.

docs.title: 2. Alphabet Series
docs.text:
These series involve letters of the alphabet arranged in a specific pattern.

How to Approach Alphabet Series: * Memorize Letter Positions: Knowing the numerical position of each letter is crucial (A=1, B=2, ..., Z=26). The mnemonic EJOTY helps you remember the positions of E(5), J(10), O(15), T(20), Y(25). * Look for Skips: Count the number of letters skipped between consecutive terms. * Example: B, E, H, K, ? * Logic: Two letters are skipped between each term (B-cd-E-fg-H-ij-K). The next term will be after skipping 'lm'. * Answer: N. * Analyze Letter Groups: For series with groups of letters (e.g., 'AZ', 'BY', 'CX'), look for patterns within the group and between the groups. * Example: AZ, BY, CX, ? * Logic: The first letter of each pair is in alphabetical order (A, B, C...). The second letter is in reverse alphabetical order (Z, Y, X...). * Answer: DW.

docs.title: 3. Figure Series (Non-Verbal Reasoning)
docs.text:
In a figure series, you are given a sequence of images and asked to choose the one that comes next.

How to Approach Figure Series: * Focus on One Element at a Time: Don't get overwhelmed. Pick one element (e.g., a dot, an arrow, a shaded region) and track its behavior across the series. * Identify the Pattern of Change: * Rotation: Is an element or the entire figure rotating? By how many degrees (45°, 90°, 180°) and in which direction (clockwise/anti-clockwise)? * Movement: Is an element moving from one position to another (e.g., corner to corner)? * Addition/Deletion: Are new elements being added or existing ones being removed in each step? * Replacement: Is one symbol being replaced by another? * Size/Shape Change: Is the figure growing, shrinking, or changing its shape?

Diagram: Figure Series Analysis (Explained in Words) Imagine a square with a dot in the top-left corner. * Step 1: Dot is at Top-Left. * Step 2: Dot moves to Top-Right. (Movement: Clockwise one step) * Step 3: Dot moves to Bottom-Right. (Movement: Clockwise one step) * Step 4: Dot moves to Bottom-Left. (Movement: Clockwise one step) * Next Figure?: The dot will move back to the Top-Left.

docs.title: AIIMS CRE-Oriented Tips & Tricks
docs.text:
• Write it Down: For number series, immediately write down the differences between the numbers. For alphabet series, write A-Z on your rough sheet. This makes patterns visible.
  • Elimination is Key: In figure series, once you identify one rule (e.g., the arrow always rotates 90° clockwise), eliminate all options that don't follow this rule.
  • Don't Overthink: The patterns are usually simple. If you find a simple, consistent rule, trust it. Don't look for overly complex solutions.
  • Practice Variety: The more types of series you practice, the faster you will become at recognizing the underlying patterns.

docs.title: Detailed Theory / Concepts
docs.text: Space visualization is the ability to mentally picture and manipulate two- and three-dimensional figures. It is a key component of non-verbal reasoning, which assesses problem-solving skills without relying on language.

docs.title: 1. Mirror and Water Images
docs.text: This involves predicting the reflection of a given figure.

docs.title: Mirror Image
docs.text:
Imagine placing a mirror along the side of the figure (usually the right side). * Rule: The image flips horizontally. * Left becomes Right, and Right becomes Left. * Top and Bottom do not change. * The part of the object closest to the mirror will be closest in the reflection.

Diagram: Mirror Image (Explained in Words) * The letter 'R' has a straight line on the left and a curve on the right. * Its mirror image will have the straight line on the right and the curve on the left, appearing as 'Я'.

docs.title: Water Image
docs.text:
Imagine a horizontal surface of water just below the figure. * Rule: The image flips vertically. * Top becomes Bottom, and Bottom becomes Top. * Left and Right do not change.

Diagram: Water Image (Explained in Words) * The letter 'F' has a vertical stem and two horizontal bars on the right at the top and middle. * Its water image will be an upside-down 'F', with the vertical stem pointing down and the two bars on the right at the bottom and middle.

docs.title: 2. Paper Folding, Cutting, and Punching
docs.text:
These problems require you to visualize the result of unfolding a piece of paper that has been folded and then cut or punched.

How to Solve: * Work Backwards: The most effective method is to mentally unfold the paper in the reverse order it was folded. * Use Symmetry: Each time you unfold the paper, the cuts and holes will be mirrored across the fold line. * If you unfold along a vertical fold, the pattern duplicates horizontally. * If you unfold along a horizontal fold, the pattern duplicates vertically.

Example: A square paper is folded in half from top to bottom, then in half again from left to right. A small circle is punched in the center of this smaller square. What will it look like when unfolded? 1. Unfold 1 (right to left): The circle in the center will be mirrored. Now you have two circles, side-by-side, in the vertical-middle of the half-folded paper. 2. Unfold 2 (bottom to top): The two circles on the bottom half will be mirrored to the top half. 3. Result: You will have four circles in the center of the full sheet, arranged in a 2x2 square.

docs.title: 3. Embedded Figures (Hidden Figures)
docs.text:
Here, you are given a simple target shape and must find it hidden within a more complex figure.

How to Solve: 1. Analyze the Target Shape: Note its key features—number of lines, angles, and orientation. 2. Scan the Complex Figure: Systematically look for the target shape. 3. Trace It: Use your finger or the tip of your pen to trace the outline of the target shape when you think you've found it. This confirms the match. 4. Check for Rotation: The problem will usually state whether the target shape can be rotated or must appear in the same orientation.

docs.title: 4. Pattern Completion
docs.text:
You are given a figure with a missing part (usually one-quarter of a square). You must choose the option that fits perfectly into the missing section to complete the overall pattern.

How to Solve: * Look for Symmetry: The pattern often has vertical, horizontal, or diagonal symmetry. The missing piece should complete this symmetry. * Follow the Lines: Trace the lines and curves from the main figure into the empty quadrant to see how they should connect. * Rotate the Options: Sometimes, mentally rotating the given options helps you see which one fits.

  • Elimination is Your Best Friend: In all non-verbal reasoning, eliminating incorrect options is much faster than confirming the correct one. If a figure needs a circle in the top-left, eliminate all options that don't have it.
  • Mirror Image of Text: To find the mirror image of a word, find the mirror image of each letter individually, and then reverse the order of the letters. The mirror image of "CRE" is "ƎЯƆ".
  • Practice, Practice, Practice: Spatial reasoning is a skill. The more you practice, the faster and more accurate your brain becomes at mentally manipulating these shapes.

docs.title: Chapter 6: Judgment, Decision Making & Problem Solving
Learning Objectives
docs.text: Upon completing this chapter, you will be able to: * Define and differentiate between problem-solving, judgment, and decision-making. * Apply a systematic, multi-step process to solve complex problems effectively. * Identify common cognitive biases that can distort judgment and lead to poor decisions. * Analyze and respond to situational judgment test (SJT) questions. * Develop a framework for making sound, ethical, and professional decisions. * Practice applying these higher-order thinking skills to relevant scenarios.

docs.title: Exam Relevance
docs.text:
• Mark Weight: Medium. While you may only see 1-2 explicit questions on this topic (often as SJTs), the skills themselves are tested implicitly throughout the exam, especially in the domain-specific section.
  • Topic Category: General Intelligence & Reasoning; Domain-Specific Knowledge.
  • Importance: High. For a professional role like Psychiatric Social Worker, demonstrating good judgment is not just about getting marks—it's a critical competency for the job itself. Strong skills here indicate a higher level of professional maturity.

docs.title: Defining the Core Concepts
docs.text:
While often used interchangeably, these three concepts are distinct parts of a larger cognitive process.

  • Problem-Solving: This is the broadest process. It involves identifying a discrepancy between a desired state and the current reality and then working to resolve that discrepancy. It is a systematic, analytical process.
  • Judgment: This is the cognitive aspect of evaluating a situation, person, or event to form an opinion or conclusion. It is the "thinking" part where you weigh options, assess evidence, and consider consequences. Good judgment is based on knowledge, experience, and critical thinking.
  • Decision-Making: This is the action-oriented output of judgment. It is the specific act of choosing one course of action from a set of alternatives. You use judgment to make a decision.

Relationship: You use judgment to analyze a problem and then make a decision on a solution.

docs.title: A 5-Step Model for Effective Problem-Solving
docs.text:
A structured approach yields better results than a haphazard one.

Diagram: The Problem-Solving Cycle (Explained in Words)

  1. Define the Problem:

    • Clearly articulate the issue. What is the root cause, and what are just symptoms?
    • Example: A patient is missing appointments. The symptom is absence. The root problem could be lack of transport, fear of side effects, or feeling better and not seeing the need.

  2. Generate Alternative Solutions:

    • Brainstorm a list of all possible actions. Don't evaluate them yet; just list them.
    • Example (for the above): Call the patient, send a reminder, ask the family for help, discuss in a team meeting, offer a tele-consultation.

  3. Evaluate and Select an Alternative:

    • Assess the pros and cons of each option. Consider feasibility, ethics, hospital policy, and potential impact on the patient.
    • Example: Calling the patient is a good first step—it's direct, respectful, and helps in gathering more information to understand the root cause.

  4. Implement the Solution:

    • Put the chosen solution into action.
    • Example: The social worker calls the patient to understand their reasons for missing the appointment.

  5. Monitor and Get Feedback:

    • Review the outcome. Did the solution work?
    • Example: The patient explains they cannot afford the bus fare. The problem is now redefined as a financial/resource issue, and the cycle begins again to solve this new, more specific problem.

docs.title: Cognitive Biases That Affect Judgment
docs.text:
Our brains use mental shortcuts (heuristics) to make quick judgments, but these can sometimes lead to systematic errors or biases.

Bias Description Example in a Clinical Setting Confirmation Bias The tendency to favor information that confirms your existing beliefs. A social worker believes a patient's family is "unsupportive" and only pays attention to evidence that proves this, ignoring instances of their support. Availability Heuristic Overestimating the importance of information that is most easily recalled. After working on a difficult case of a rare disorder, a clinician starts seeing signs of it in other patients, even when it's unlikely. Anchoring Bias Relying too heavily on the first piece of information you receive. The first report on a patient says they are "difficult." This "anchor" may cause the team to interpret all subsequent behaviors negatively. Halo Effect Letting a single positive trait (e.g., being well-spoken) create an overall positive impression that clouds judgment on other traits. A patient is articulate and polite, so the clinician assumes they are also highly motivated and compliant with treatment, which may not be true.

docs.title: Situational Judgment Tests (SJTs)
docs.text:
SJTs are designed to assess how you would handle realistic work-related situations.

How to Approach SJT Questions: 1. Identify the Core Issue: Is the scenario about ethics, patient safety, teamwork, confidentiality, or following rules? 2. Look for the Proactive & Professional Choice: The best answer is usually one that is constructive, responsible, and collaborative. It solves the problem without creating new ones. 3. Eliminate Inappropriate Actions: * Passive Actions: "Do nothing," "ignore it," or "wait for someone else to handle it." * Aggressive Actions: Confronting someone angrily, breaking rules, or acting unilaterally without consultation. * Passing the Buck: Immediately telling your superior without first gathering basic facts or trying to handle it at the appropriate level.

docs.title: AIIMS CRE-Oriented Tips & Tricks
docs.text:
• Prioritize Patient Welfare: In any clinical scenario, the patient's safety, rights, and well-being are the top priority.
  • Follow the Hierarchy: The best action often involves consulting with the right person—your immediate supervisor, the doctor in charge, or the multidisciplinary team.
  • Embrace Teamwork: Solutions that involve collaboration are almost always better than acting alone.
  • Know Your Role: The ideal response for a social worker is one that aligns with the professional functions of assessment, counseling, advocacy, and resource mobilization. A social worker does not prescribe medicine or make a medical diagnosis.

What is the best course of action? a) Accept it, as it would be rude to refuse. b) Politely decline, explaining that it is against hospital policy. c) Accept the gift and share it with the entire team. d) Ask them to give it to your supervisor instead.

  7. You are running a support group, and two members get into a heated argument. What should you do? a) Ask one of them to leave the group. b) Intervene, validate both perspectives, and guide the conversation back to the group rules. c) End the group session immediately. d) Let them argue it out, as conflict is natural.
